{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3589208,"name":"Isaiah Ballestrazze","username":"Strazze","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/58f4c7/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-04-11T20:37:08.341Z","cooked":"

I have recently undertaken the task of creating the first mini Romi swerve bot.

I’m unsure if it’s possible but the goal is to build a smaller version of our current drive train in order to teach some younger members of our team how to program it. We are using YAGSL so I want to use the same library on this bot.

10000004891920×1080 264 KB

Currently I have run into an issue with the quadrature encoders. On the Romi’s there are assignable pins that you can configure with the Online Web UI. I configured all of them to DIO and created a command in the code that will read the pins and print out a true or false. This worked great and I could see the differences as I slowly turned the motor wheel. However when I went to make an Encoder constructor, and print out a raw encoder.get() value all I got was zeros. If you have any suggestions for me to try it would be highly appreciated! I would put more images but it wont let me.

My Code:

github.com

GitHub - IsaiahBallestrazze/Romi2025

Contribute to IsaiahBallestrazze/Romi2025 development by creating an account on GitHub.

I suspect that you would need to make custom Romi firmware to support more then the 2 encoders.

github.com

wpilibsuite/wpilib-ws-robot-romi/blob/main/firmware/README.md

# WPILibWS Reference Robot (Romi 32U4)
This README provides information about how to prepare your Romi 32U4 board for use with the WPILib WebSocket extension.

## Overview
Out of the box, the Romi 32U4 acts as an Arduino compatible microcontroller, with several built in actuators and inputs (e.g. buttons, motors, encoders, etc). We will leverage these built in components in a way that also allows interoperability with WPILib code.

### Port mapping differences between RoboRIO and Romi 32U4
The RoboRIO provides separate banks for Digital IO, Analog In, Relays and PWM Out. On the Romi 32U4, many of the exposed ports can have multiple functions (e.g. a digital IO port can also be configured as an analog in port).

To fit in with the RoboRIO/WPILib model of separate banks, we configure the pins/devices available on the Romi 32U4 board into separate banks as well. While this reduces the flexibility of port configuration somewhat, it makes it easier to get started with running WPILib-based robot code with the Romi robot.

## Hardware Modifications
To allow connecting to additional inputs/actuators (e.g. distance sensors or servos), we select a set of 5 pins on the Romi 32U4 board, and add pin headers to them. These pins are:

- Pin 11
- Pin 4 / Analog 6
- Pin 20 / Analog 2
- Pin 21 / Analog 3
- Pin 22 / Analog 4
This file has been truncated. show original

There are a couple of XRP system swerve adaptations out there. I believe the XRP board supports 4 encoders natively.

Printables.com

Omnidirectional XRP Robot by WildWilly | Download free STL model |...

Swerve drivetrain for XRP | Download free 3D printable STL models

Printables.com

XRP Differential Swerve Drive Robot! by Jacob Williams | Download free STL...

Differential Swerve Drive Robot with the XRP system! 100% plastic modules, mostly printed! | Download free 3D printable STL models

Im just looking at the XRP board, I can use the onboard Motor controllers to control the azimuth motors, then I could use the DIO ports for direction and a PWM for the speed. I just need to figure out how to do digital outputs for the board in wpilib java. I also need to figure out how to use the pwm port directly without the servo class thingy. I’ll do some more research.
